The Education 4.0 India report presents a roadmap to address all four areas to enhance India’s school education ecosystem and calls for a multistakeholder collaboration to transform the sector. Read the full report https://t.co/kLv91svDj5
And the fourth highlights the digital divide, made worse by the pandemic.
The school-to-work transition makes up the third priority area to make students job-ready in a rapidly evolving employment landscape.
The second focus area for interventions involves enhancing teachers’ capacity to deliver education in newer formats.

First, a significant gap identified in foundational learning and numeracy is the lack of "byte-sized" content in early education that can ignite a child's interest & engage parents who may not be educated.
The report identifies gaps and recommends intervention in 4 key areas: foundational learning and numeracy (FLN), teachers’ capacity building, school-to-work transition and connecting the unconnected.

The COVID-19 pandemic widened the gaps in learning for children and educators alike. 

The new Education 4.0 India report, an initiative by @wef, @UNICEF and @YuWaahIndia, identifies learning gaps in India and solutions to make education accessible to all. https://t.co/Ljo3TXckZr

The food system must learn from the energy sector’s transformation says Qu Dongyu @FAODG. We also need innovation and policy with a purpose and a stronger commitment from politicians. #BoldActions4Food @FAO
Food systems change must be on the agenda at #COP27 the panelists all agree and governments must incentivize decarbonization through subsidies. #BoldActions4Food

A holistic approach involving all stakeholders is crucial says @chefsamkass. Food companies must be transparent about their carbon footprint, so consumers can choose who they support. #BoldActions4Food

Hanneke Faber @unilever says consumers can help by choosing plant-based diets and reducing food waste. ‘We’re using too much land and producing greenhouse gases to produce all that food we don’t end up using.’ #BoldActions4Food

Rodrigo Santos @bayer says we need innovation, collaboration and action to transform the global food system and to involve farmers: ‘We need to bring them to the table, they’re part of the solution.’ #BoldActions4Food

Jürgen Vögele @worldbank says war in Ukraine is exacerbating the global food crisis and the effects will be long lasting. The severity ‘greatly depends’ on the policies countries put in place. #BoldActions4Food

Digital inclusion has a vital role to play in areas from banking to employment, says @hooilingtan. But how does the private sector create products and services that are most needed by their users?
.@adrianlovett of @webfoundation agrees - investment in this area could reap huge rewards. But, we need the resources to take advantage and spread connectivity.
Private businesses have a major role to play, says @RFS_Vista of @Vista_Equity, in partnering with the public sector and communities - but if we get it right, the potential economic uplift is huge.
We need a whole society approach, says @ASteiner of @UNDP. You need a digital ecosystem that allows start-ups, programmers to thrive, but that's also inclusive and doesn't leave people behind.
In areas like fintech, countries like Kenya and Rwanda are helping lead the way in terms of deployment and regulation, says @OmarSAlolama. But, infrastructure development is critical.

Digital technologies have the potential to help developing economies leapfrog traditional development stages, says @MusoniPaula. But, inclusion is important and we need to build partnerships to build capacity and encourage adoption.

We need to scale existing technologies and drive investment and commitments for emerging solutions, explains @Antoniagawel. And this needs to happen across the value chain.
To do this, partnerships are key, says @Holcim's Jan Jenisch. And we need to raise awareness of the products that are already available, so customers know they already have a choice.
For example, nobody is producing green fuels for shipping, because nobody is using them, says @SorenSkou of @Maersk. So we need to create markets, create demand, he says.
The faster we introduce these products and increase demand for them, the sooner we'll achieve our climate goals, Kerry says. We can't afford to sit around and wait. @ClimateEnvoy

'The race is on' says @ClimateEnvoy John Kerry to reduce emissions, with technology set to play a vital role. We need to increase demand for green products - particularly in sectors that are hard to decarbonize.

Walter Schalka explained that the time for action is now. We can't procrastinate and leave it to future generations, he told #ClimateBreakthroughs.

For @RhianMariThomas, CEO of @GFI_green, it's clear that we need to divert capital to nature-positive actions. @WDraijer agreed on the vital role of finance - if flows can be opened up.

#ClimateBreakthroughs

The panel agreed on the potential of nature-based solutions, with @gmunozabogabir explaining that they're already proving to be cost-effective and scalable. However, @inger_andersen reminded us that they're not a replacement for decarbonization.

.@AnkitiB of @Zilingo says digital adoption is freeing up 5-10% of margins in the fashion and textile industry to help brands focus on #ESG. Technology enables greater transparency on sustainability issues such as how much water was used.

Trade is helping to save lives, says @BaldwinRE. “We now understand unless #COVID19 is over everywhere, it’s over nowhere. It’s the same with climate and food stocks - COVID has alerted us to all these issues.”
.@HenadiS of @Agility says digital is driving resilience and democratizing trade. “E-commerce has potential to make trade more inclusive for SMEs and women.”
.@DanTehanWannon says there’s never been a more important time for us to get the focus back on the @WTO and improve trade rules. “Trade liberalization will help countries grow out of this pandemic.”

Global solidarity is the need of the hour says @PiyushGoyal on the #COVID19 crisis. “This current situation needs extraordinary measures and out-of-the-box solutions… Together our efforts will break through.”

.@WTO needs to have success this year, says @NOIweala. “We can no longer take 20 years to negotiate outcomes if the WTO is about people, enhancing living standards, creating employment and sustainable development.”

.@NOIweala of @WTO says getting vaccine distribution right would see an additional 2% bounce in trade value. “Vaccine policy is economic policy, we have to get that right if we want a sustained recovery.”

.@HelenClarkNZ calls for the world to come together now "around a stronger system to support preparedness and response" to pandemics.

Affordable clean energy solutions can tackle #energypoverty. @SmartWiresinc #energytransition #reimaginethegrid @wefenergy https://t.co/daj6S4RjIS https://t.co/IXgxN7n3Es https://t.co/BGIM9lSDLo

.@lyndagratton says we become healthy when we do healthy work. We need to build flexibility, increase capability through upskilling, and build in predictability. Governments and corporations need to show what the new jobs are and what skills are needed.

The pandemic has shown the old healthcare systems were not good enough for this world, says @shobanakamineni. India has become more agile and digital healthcare has become ubiquitous. This will transform the health systems of countries and make it more inclusive. @HospitalsApollo

.@MikeFroman of @Mastercard says we need to build back in an inclusive and sustainable way. We need to be very attentive towards modernizing our social safety net. #COVID19 underscored how important it is for people to be connected to the digital economy.

We need to think of preparedness as a global public good, says @HelenClarkNZ. Leaders need to come together, review what has happened and determine to improve national preparedness systems. They need to be peer reviewed.

.@HelenClarkNZ says despite years of warnings, many countries weren’t prepared for #COVID19. 'The system must be based on the most up-to-date tools and AI to report pandemic threats in hours. In the 21st century these pathogens can be on the next plane, there’s no time to waste.'

In 2020, under the pressure of the crisis, too much of the response was nation states, says @matthancock. We need a cohesive global response, it's important we work together to drive up vaccine supply and have rules in place to allow safe travel.

.@matthancock says the 'holy trinity' of government, academia and enterprise has been crucial to the UK's #COVID19 vaccine roll-out success. It was a national mission, with one cohesive team with a single, clear mission, to vaccinate the UK as fast as possible, and the world.

.@zahidi says governments need to invest in the care sector, a huge job creator, and firms need to hardwire gender equality. But there are still too many parts of world where health and education still have massive gender gaps. #gendergap21

Natalie Lacey of @ipsos says companies and countries need to acknowledge gender gaps and recognize the change that needs to happen. It’s not just about flexible hours, it’s about support services and broader ways to allow women to fulfil their expectations and needs. #gendergap21

Sue Duke of @LinkedIn says we need a 'fundamental shift' away from formal qualifications and to look at women's untapped potential. 'If we can help them reskill and retrain, we can get women into those positions and that is going to be for the good of us all.' #gendergap21

@zahidi says all sectors need to value different kinds of work. #COVID19 has shown women are frontline workers, from grocery stores to healthcare. Traditional female-dominated industries need to think about improving skill level and wages. #gendergap21
Sue Duke of @LinkedIn says the pandemic has called into question all aspects of how we live. We need to hardwire equity, diversity and sustainability into the recovery. #gendergap21
Sue Duke of @LinkedIn says there's not enough progress in high-growth roles like cloud computing and data. Those are the jobs of tomorrow and we need women in those roles. #gendergap21
Natalie Lacey of @ipsos says 50% of countries feel the gender pay gap is a real problem, but we still have a 'sizeable minority' who believe it doesn't exist. #gendergap21

Volkmar Denner @BoschGlobal 'Our people are proud to work in a #gln21 factory. We put people at the centre – you can use digital tools to replace jobs, but we try to make people even more valuable. We try to free them up from tedious, dangerous work.' #gln21 @McKinsey

Kexing Huang @tsingtaouk says consumers now expect a good product, and a company with values that produces in a green way. 'Tech can improve our efficiency and reduce energy consumption and incorporate green and sustainable development to the whole value chain.' #gln21 @McKinsey
Paul Fang @MideaGulf says, 'Data allows us to have insights on consumer trends and new needs and react faster and provide better service to our customers.' #gln21 @McKinsey

Carsten Knobel @Henkel says they have reduced CO2 emissions by 10%. Industry 4.0 and technologies of the #4IR  are the key lever to drive sustainable growth. Machine learning can optimize energy intensive processes. #gln21 @McKinsey

Börje Ekholm @Ericsson says: 'It’s good business sense to put sustainability at the centre. Our factory in Dallas improves the resilience of our supply chain. If we build factories in a sustainable way, it will cut energy consumption, serve customers better.' #gln21 @McKinsey

Upskilling the workforce is key for @BuschRo @siemens. He says the combination of the digital and physical 'allows us to do more with less and be more flexible and run different products for customers'. #gln21 @McKinsey

T. V. Narendran @TataSteelLtd: 'To mobilize the entire workforce for digital transformation, we asked people down the line what can we do with tech to make your life easier? Once you have that kind of buy-in, you can make changes across the whole organization.' #gln21 @McKinsey

@EnriqueJLores says for @HP, ‘innovating with purpose’ is about the impact they’re having on the environment and in the communities. ‘We need to continue to aspire to drive changes in our overall ecosystem, I am very optimistic about where we can go in future.’ #gln21 @McKinsey

@JNJNews and @satyanadella @Microsoft agree that collaboration and knowledge sharing are crucial to the manufacturing, healthcare and technology sectors in future. A focus on sustainability, innovation, skilling, wellbeing and culture is paramount. #gln21 @McKinsey

Alex Gorsky @JNJNews says the application of digitalization and new technologies were crucial to #COVID19 vaccine development as vaccine design was enabled by data sciences and clinical trials were a large database exercise. #gln21 @McKinsey
